message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Urinary output is the most appropriate method to verify adequate fluid infusion in this patient. The Parkland formula is used to calculate the amount of fluid needed for burn resuscitation, but it is not a method to verify adequate fluid infusion. Blood pressure and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure are not specific enough to determine fluid status.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most appropriate way to verify adequate fluid infusion in a patient with burns is by monitoring urinary output. The Parkland formula is used to calculate the amount of fluid resuscitation needed for burn patients, but it does not verify adequate infusion. Blood pressure and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure may also be monitored, but they do not directly reflect fluid infusion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The Parkland formula is used only for burns affecting more than 20% of the total body surface area. Blood pressure and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure can be affected by various factors and do not provide a direct assessment of fluid status. Urinary output is a reliable indicator of the adequacy of fluid resuscitation after burns. Therefore, urinary output is the most appropriate method to verify adequate fluid infusion.

Therefore, urinary output is the most reliable method to assess fluid status.

The Parkland formula is used to calculate the fluid replacement required in the first 24 hours, and blood pressure and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure may not always be accurate indicators of fluid status in burn patients.

Blood pressure and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure can be influenced by various factors and are not reliable indicators of fluid resuscitation.
